com.ibm.mqtt
Class MqttClient

java.lang.Object
  MqttBaseClient
      com.ibm.mqtt.MqttClient
All Implemented Interfaces:
IMqttClient
public class MqttClient
extends MqttBaseClient
implements IMqttClient

The MqttClient Java class provides an API for the WebSphere MQ Telemetry Transport. See IMqttClient for more information.

Constructor Detail

MqttClient

protected MqttClient()
Default constructor. The initialise method must be called before the MqttClient is usable.

MqttClient

public MqttClient(java.lang.String theConnection)
           throws MqttException
The MqttClient constructor - no persistence

Parameters:
theConnection - A connection string that indicates how the client should connect to the broker

TCP/IP connection string:tcp://broker_IP_address:port
Local binding connection string:local://brokerName

Throws:
MqttException - If a suitable adapter for the connection method cannot be found
MqttException.MqttException.getCause() will give more information. If writing J2ME MIDlets then make sure that the class com.ibm.mqtt.midp.MqttMidpSocket is not optimised out of the jar file - see PDF documentation.
See Also:
createMqttClient(String, MqttPersistence)

MqttClient

public MqttClient(java.lang.String theConnection,
                  MqttPersistence persistence)
           throws MqttException
The MqttClient constructor - optional persistence

Parameters:
connection - A connection string that indicates how the client should connect to the broker

TCP/IP connection string:tcp://broker_IP_address@port
Local binding connection string:local://brokerName
persistence - The persistence implementation to use with the client. If persistence is not required use hte other constructor.
Throws:
MqttException - If a suitable adapter for the connection method cannot be found
MqttException.MqttException.getCause() will give more information. If writing J2ME MIDlets then make sure that the class com.ibm.mqtt.midp.MqttMidpSocket is not optimised out of the jar file - see PDF documentation.
See Also:
MqttPersistence, createMqttClient(String, MqttPersistence)

                                                 MqttPersistence persistence)
                                          throws MqttException
Get a new instance of a MQTT client.

Parameters:
connection - A connection string that indicates how the client should connect to the broker

TCP/IP connection string:tcp://broker_IP_address@port
Local binding connection string:local://brokerName
persistence - The persistence implementation to use with the client. Specify null if no persistence is required.
Throws:
MqttException - If a suitable adapter for the connection method cannot be found
MqttException. MqttException.getCause() will give more information. If writing J2ME MIDlets then make sure that the class com.ibm.mqtt.midp.MqttMidpSocket is not optimised out of the jar file - see PDF documentation.

startTrace

public void startTrace()
                throws MqttException
Start tracing the WMQTT Java client. The trace will be produced in a binary format in the current directory. The trace file is called mqe0.trc. Execute java -jar MqttTraceFormat.jar mqe0.trc > a.out to format the trace into a readable format. Tracing is currently only available for the J2SE implementation.

Specified by:
startTrace in interface IMqttClient
Throws:
MqttException - If the WMQTT com.ibm.mqtt.trace classes cannot be found or if errors occur instantiating the trace classes.

stopTrace

public void stopTrace()
Stop tracing the WMQtt Java client. This will close the trace file in the current directory.

Specified by:
stopTrace in interface IMqttClient

connect

public void connect(java.lang.String clientid,
                    boolean cleanstart,
                    short keepalive)
             throws MqttException,
                    MqttPersistenceException,
                    MqttBrokerUnavailableException,
                    MqttNotConnectedException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Connect to the WebSphere Business Integration broker. If the application is already connected then this method does nothing.

Specified by:
connect in interface IMqttClient
Parameters:
clientid - A character identfier which must be unique across all MQTT connections to the WebSphere Business Integration broker. Max length is 23 characters.
cleanstart - A boolean indicating if the broker should cleanup if the TCP/IP connection terminates.
  • TRUE - This will leave the broker in a state as though the client had never connected. All publications and subscriptions related to that client will be deleted.
  • FALSE - State will be preserved in the broker, so that the client may resume where it left off when it next connects
cleanstart should be used for applications that do not require messages to be queued up whilst they are disconnected, or for applications that always require to start in a known clean state.
If cleanstart is enabled then the broker is instructed to violate its assured delivery contract for QoS 1 and 2 publications in the event that the connection is terminated between client and broker. It will delete all state including that for partially delivered publications.
keepalive - An interval in seconds that the broker should use to determine if the MQTT client is still alive. If data is not received within this interval the broker will assume the client has terminated and disconnect it, cleaning up if the clean start flag was specified. If the connection is inactive for keepalive seconds this client library will automatically ping the connection to keep it alive until an explicit disconnect is issued.
Throws:
MqttNotConnectedException - If a TCP/IP connection was made to the broker, but the broker did not send the MQTT CONNACK response - try increasing the retry interval.
MqttBrokerUnavailableException - If the broker CONNACK message indicates the broker cannot accept connections at the moment. Retry the connect periodically.
MqttPersistenceException - If there was a problem opening, reseting or reading sent or received messages from the persistent store.
MqttException - If an error response was received from the broker, or if there were problems with the TCP/IP socket connection. MqttException.getCause() may give more information.
See Also:
IMqttClient.connect(String, boolean, short)

connect

public void connect(java.lang.String clientid,
                    boolean cleanstart,
                    short keepalive,
                    java.lang.String willtopic,
                    int willQoS,
                    java.lang.String willmsg,
                    boolean willretain)
             throws MqttException,
                    MqttPersistenceException,
                    MqttBrokerUnavailableException,
                    MqttNotConnectedException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Connect to the WebSphere Business Integration broker. If the application is already connected then this method does nothing.

Specified by:
connect in interface IMqttClient
Parameters:
clientid - As above
cleanstart - As above.
keepalive - As above.
willtopic - In the event of the MQTT connection unexpectedly terminating the broker will publish a 'Last Will and Testament' message on this topic.
willQoS - Publish the last will and testament message at this Quality of Service (0,1 or 2).
willmsg - In the event of the MQTT connection unexpectedly terminating the broker will publish this data on the above topic.
willretain - A boolean indicating if the 'Last Will and Testament' message should be a retained publication.
Throws:
MqttNotConnectedException - If a TCP/IP connection was made to the broker, but the broker did not send the MQTT CONNACK response - try increasing the retry interval.
MqttBrokerUnavailableException - If the broker CONNACK message indicates the broker cannot accept connections at the moment. Retry the connect periodically.
MqttPersistenceException - If there was a problem opening, reseting or reading sent or received messages from the persistent store.
MqttException - If an error response was received from the broker, or if there were problems with the TCP/IP socket connection. MqttException.getCause() may give more information.
See Also:
IMqttClient.connect(String, boolean, short, String, int, String, boolean)

connectionLost

protected void connectionLost()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
Default behaviour is to throw an exception which will stop any further API calls succeeding. An application should reconnect to send and receive any further data.

Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:

notifyAck

protected void notifyAck(int ref,
                         int msgId)
API methods connect, subscribe and unsubscribe are synchronous, so that the API does not return until the WMQtt acknowledgment message has been received. After sending the WMQTT protocol message the user thread waits until it is woken up by this method to indicate that an acknowledgement has been received from the broker. Parameters: ref - The type of object to notify of an acknowledgement arriving msgid - The message identifier for which an acknowledgement has been received

ping

public void ping()
          throws MqttException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Send a MQTT ping message to indicate that the MQTT client is alive. Sending of ping messages within the keepalive interval is automatically handled by the MQTT client library. However an application can also initiate a ping exchange if it so desires.

Specified by:
ping in interface IMqttClient
Throws:
MqttException - If the ping cannot be written to the TCP/IP socket. MqttException.getCause() will give more information.
See Also:
IMqttClient.ping()

publish

public int publish(java.lang.String thisTopic,
                   byte[] thisMessage,
                   int thisQoS,
                   boolean retained)
            throws MqttNotConnectedException,
                   MqttPersistenceException,
                   MqttException,
                   java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Publish a message on a particular topic to the WebSphere Business Integration broker.

Apart from MqttPersistenceException all other exceptions thrown by this method are a result of an application coding error and should be found during testing.

Specified by:
publish in interface IMqttClient
Parameters:
thisTopic - A string containing the topic on which the associated data should be published.
thisMessage - A byte array containing the data to be published on the above topic.
thisQoS - The Quality of Service which the message should be delivered at.
  • QoS 0 - Delivered at most once ( 0 or 1 times)
  • QoS 1 - Delivered at least once ( 1 or more times)
  • QoS 2 - Delivered only once
retained - - boolean flag indicating whether the publication should be retained by the broker or not.
Returns:
The message identifier of the published message.
Throws:
MqttNotConnectedException - If the client is in a disconnected state. i.e. Either connect has never been called, or connectionLost has been called because of a TCP/IP interruption.
MqttPersistenceException - If the persistence implementation fails when sending a publication. No publication is sent and it is not queued for retrying.
MqttException - If parameters are incorrect or any other kind of error occurs. Use MqttException.getCause() to determine the problem. No publication is sent and it is not queued for retrying.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If any parameters are null, or the topic contains invalid characters.
See Also:
IMqttClient.publish(String, byte[], int, boolean)

                              byte[] message,
                              int QoS,
                              boolean retained)
                       throws java.lang.Exception
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
MqttSimpleCallback.publishArrived(String, byte[], int, boolean)

terminate

public void terminate()
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
This method terminates all running threads in the MqttClient instance. This method should be called after disconnect, when the MqttClient instance has been finished with. If you haven't disconnected from the broker then the method will disconnect for you. Once terminate has been called any further method calls on the MqttClient instance will fail.

Specified by:
terminate in interface IMqttClient
See Also:
IMqttClient.terminate()

terminate

public void terminate(boolean doDisconnect)
This method terminates all running threads in the MqttClient instance. This method should be called after disconnect, when the MqttClient instance has been finished with. Once terminate has been called any further method calls on the MqttClient instance will fail.

Parameters:
doDisconnect - true - indicates that the application wants this method terminate to disconnect on its behalf (if it hasn't already)
false - The method will not disconnect on the applications behalf (useful for testing Last Will and Testament). Terminating without disconnecting will appear to the broker as though the application has died.

subscribe

public int subscribe(java.lang.String[] theseTopics,
                     int[] theReqQoS)
              throws MqttNotConnectedException,
                     MqttException,
                     java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Subscribe to one or more topics.

Specified by:
subscribe in interface IMqttClient
Parameters:
theseTopics - An array of topics. Each topic is a character string and may contain wildcard charaters # or +.
Returns:
The message id of the subscribe message. This can be used to correlate the subscribe with the acknowledgment received via the subscribed callback method.
Throws:
MqttNotConnectedException - If the client is in a disconnected state. i.e. Either connect has never been called, or connectionLost has been called because of a TCP/IP interruption.
MqttException - If the outcome of the subscribe is unknown. Be aware in this case that the subscription may be successfully registered with the broker, but a response was not received, possibly due to network errors. Retry the subscribe. MqttException.getCause() may give more information.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If any parameters are null.
See Also:
IMqttClient.subscribe(String[], int[])

unsubscribe

public int unsubscribe(java.lang.String[] theseTopics)
                throws MqttNotConnectedException,
                       MqttException,
                       java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Description copied from interface: IMqttClient
Unsubscribe from one or more topics.

Specified by:
unsubscribe in interface IMqttClient
Parameters:
theseTopics - An array of topics. Each topic is a character string that may contain wildcard characters # or +.
Returns:
The message id of the unsubscribe message. This can be used to correlate the unsubscribe with the acknowledgment received via the unsubscribed callback method.
Throws:
MqttNotConnectedException - If the client is in a disconnected state. i.e. Either connect has never been called, or connectionLost has been called because of a TCP/IP interruption.
MqttException - If the outcome of the unsubscribe is unknown. Be aware in this case that the subscription may be successfully deregistered with the broker, but a response was not received, possibly due to network errors. Retry the unsubscribe. MqttException.getCause() may give more information.
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If any parameters are null.
See Also:
IMqttClient.unsubscribe(String[])
